outputs.output_descr:
Phase 1: Identification

1.	Conduct a feasibility study for the establishment of the Center in Raqqa
2.	Determine secondary purposes of the Center with relevance to the local context, in close coordination with the local Chamber of Commerce
3.	Determine eligibility criteria for candidate entrepreneurs 
4.	Design the Center's business plan, resources and cost-recovery structure to ensure its sustainability 
5.	Detail the support services to be provided by the Center
6.	Appoint the Center's director and team 

Phase 2: Implementation

According to the findings and recommendations resulting from the preliminary stage, this phase will comprise of the following activities: 

1.	Rehabilitate selected premises 
2.	Set up an ICT Hub (service provider) in partnership with government, NGOs, professional associations, local authorities and the private sector
3.	Launch the selection process of local entrepreneurs 
4.	Provide MSMEs with relevant Center support, such as:  
	Provide training in human and financial resources management
	Provide orientation on marketing and promotion techniques 
	Provide training on strategic planning and product life cycle
	Provide access to international competitiveness benchmarks aimed at improving the quality of Syrian MSMEs products 
	Assist in conducting feasibility studies for new ideas developed by entrepreneurs
	Develop an SME Info Portal and Toolkit and design information manage                                               ment tools
5.	Conduct publicity campaigns to develop entrepreneurship especially among Women and Youth 
6.	Organize conferences and local business networks through which MSMEs can share experience

Organize public events, presentations and consultations on the adoption of new production technologies and the use of ICT.

Phase 3: Evaluation
For accurate evaluation, the Center's performance and sustainability may be measured against the following benchmarks:

1.	Performance outcomes  which include program sustainability (revenues and costs generated) and growth, tenant firms' survival and growth (both in terms of sales revenue and capital), contribution to the Center's sponsors mission, and community-related impacts (employment created and sustained).
2.	Management Policies and their effectiveness  measuring the effective use of resources against the Center's objectives. The elements assessed include the goals, organization and governance of the incubator, financing and capitalization, operational policies and target markets.
3.	Services and their value added  assessment of the perceived value added to the supported firms in terms of services and facilities provided, and the perceived value associated to the knowledge sharing and to the Center's environment.

The project is intended to address the urgent needs to provide vocational training due to the lack of skilled labor in the region. It also aims to assist the newly graduated youths to upgrade their skills and be prepared for regional markets, in order to increase local employment opportunities. This will address the government's objective and priority in development of the region through inviting more investments which needs trained and competent human resources locally to support their operations. This also ultimately will contribute to the government's goal of poverty eradication in the region. 
This objective will be achieved by professional trainings tailored according to the market needs and the students' specialties. The training curriculum and syllabus will be identified and developed based on the initial survey in the region with expertise and experience of UNRWA training center in Damascus.

Considering the drought situation and scarcity of water in the north eastern region, the wells have been left neglected and gone out of use.  In Der ez Zor and Hassakeh Governorates, respectively 30% and 7% of wells have gone out of service during the past four years. Inhabitants of many villages depend on water trucking

Given the above context, the rehabilitation of Roman Wells in the North Eastern region will strongly contribute to achieving the access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation.  Hence ensuring access to clean water resources will improve the living hand health standards, and decrease internal migration, in the North Eastern region through increased access to safe drinking water and will help reduce the severe diarrhea cases resulted from drought and lack of water.
  
As North eastern region is one of the poorest regions, hence it is considered as one of the priority development areas by the national authoritiesnt for poverty reduction efforts; hence this project is fully in line with national priorities and the UN efforts for complementing governmental efforts to assist people affected by drought.   

The rehabilitation of wells in the Eastern Region will increase the quality and availability of water for the households in the least developed part of Syria, or more than 1000 residents (direct beneficiaries), with a higher indirect benefit to the non-residents of the whole area.   

Based on UNDP survey, there are approximately 129 wells in Der ez Zor Governorate only and over 200 wells in the 3 governorates.  UNDP has already rehabilitated   35 wells and UNDP now is working on restoring another 9 wells in Deir Ez zour governorate. 
This project aims at rehabilitating ancient Roman Wells in the north eastern region in one of the poorest regions of the country, , for use as a sustainable water source by the local population, without incurring environmental damages.  This is expected to increase the access of the local population in the north eastern region to safe drinking water.

project_descr: Support for Bus. Innovation and Development Center in Der Ezzor
project_title: Support for Bus. Innovation and Dev. Center in Der Ezzor
